speaker: ira glass
utterance: Act Two, State of Emergency. So our show today is about people trying to find their way in situations where they don't have much information, or anyway the information they need. And, of course, that's the situation the whole world is in right now with the spread of COVID-19 as we try to make sense of how to treat it, how to deal with it as a society.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Couple weeks ago, my co-worker Miki Meek talked to one emergency medical worker in Brooklyn, Anthony Almojera. He's vice president of local 3621 of the EMS Officers Union in New York City. EMS, emergency medical services-- it's part of the fire department. Even a few weeks ago, they were totally overwhelmed. Anthony was out responding to an endless stream of 911 calls.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And Miki checked back in with him recently to see how he's doing. He said that even though the number of infections in the city has finally started to slow, his crew is still in uncharted territory. And a lot of the calls they're getting are for cardiac arrest. Apparently the virus, in addition to attacking the lungs, can also put stress on the heart and sometimes directly infect the heart.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Some days, the number of cardiac arrest calls coming into New York City's 911 system has been huge, over 300. It's about four times higher than before the pandemic. Most of those people are dying at home. Here's Miki talking to Anthony and then to one of his colleagues.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Anthony, how are you doing?

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: I'm OK, I guess. It's still crazy. This past Sunday, I did 13 cardiac arrests in a 16-hour shift.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Jeez, 13.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: 13 cardiac arrests-- what does that day look like for you?

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: So I wake up. I put the uniform on. I'm sitting there, trying to mentally get myself geared up for another day of this.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: I get a Red Bull. If you're going to be in the middle of hell, you might as well be alert. And I'm going to work, and my brain is sitting there-- it's weird because my brain is sitting there going, OK, I got to get ready because I know it's coming. Then it starts coming. 6:30 in the morning, it started coming.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: I go. Elderly gentleman-- fever, cough, symptoms. We try and work him up. We were unsuccessful. I tell the family, I'm sorry. There's nothing more we can do.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: And then I go back into the truck. I hit the button. I get called for the other cardiac arrests. And I go, another family, the patient's family saying that he had a cough for five days and he was weak with chills. We try and work him up, we're unsuccessful. We pronounce.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: I hit the button. I get hit again for another cardiac arrest. I go. This particular patient we weren't able to work up because he had rigor mortis, so he had been dead for a little while.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: But the family states, oh, he had fever, cough symptoms. So we were like, OK. I'm sorry for your loss. There's another one that happened today. I'm sorry for your loss.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: And then the next call-- and this is going to sound weird to the everyday person, but the next call was a suicide. There's no fever, cough. So it's like, oh, a regular call, so to speak, as opposed to having to get all crazy with the gowns, and the gloves, and the masks. It's such a morbid scene, but there's three of us that are like, well, this is one patient we don't have to worry about getting this virus from. And it's like, to feel relief in the middle of this tragic death-- I mean, this is somebody who felt hopeless enough to go and commit suicide. We still have the empathy for him and whatnot, but hey, we're going to get through this one without getting infected by anything.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: And then I hit the button. The button shows that I'm available. And I'm on my way to another cardiac arrest.

speaker: cassandra
utterance: I've never had a panic or an anxiety attack, and I feel like one is going to come on really soon.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: This is another paramedic in New York City I'm calling Cassandra. She didn't want me to use her real name because she didn't get permission from the fire department to talk to me. I've been checking in with her regularly over the past few weeks, and she's processing her days differently than Anthony.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Because she's not a lieutenant, she spends her entire 12-hour day in an ambulance. I talked to her recently after she'd finished one of her shifts. She'd gotten home at 3:00 AM and took a bubble bath to try and calm down, but it didn't work.

speaker: cassandra
utterance: How much more worse than this can it get? We're at worst to me. This is my worst. I did 37 cardiac arrests last week. I told somebody I'm sorry for your loss 37 times last week.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: 37 times I'm sorry for your loss.

speaker: cassandra
utterance: Yeah. And-- yeah. I don't think I've ever done that in a year, like 37 cardiac arrests. That's insane to me. I don't even know how to explain it. Like, my soul hurts. I'm not used to seeing all this death all at once.

speaker: cassandra
utterance: I'm a person. I'm very strong headed. So it's just like, if I see death it's like, OK, this happened. I process it quick. And I'm like, I deliver my message to the family.

speaker: cassandra
utterance: And it's like, damn, that was messed up. And I move on. It's not like it sticks with me for a while. And right now that's not the case. I'm holding each and every one of them in because I don't have time to just put it away.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: I was wondering, are there any particular calls that stick with you right now?

speaker: cassandra
utterance: There was actually one cardiac arrest that I had last week that wasn't COVID related. But the guy was 107 years old, and he was fighting. He really wanted to live. And I was shocked at that.

speaker: cassandra
utterance: And that made me a little bit happy because I thought we were going to get him back. We didn't. We pronounced him at the end, but he was fighting. He really wanted to live.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: What do you fear most right now? Like, what's the fear that's on your mind this morning?

speaker: cassandra
utterance: I'm a ticking bomb. If I don't start dealing with stuff, I'm going to blow up on my partner or on somebody. And God forbid that's on a patient because I don't want to be mean to somebody that just lost a loved one, you know what I mean? I don't know how I'm going to react to not dealing with all this death constantly.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Do you have a plan?

speaker: cassandra
utterance: I don't. I don't have time to make a plan.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Anthony, when I talked to you last, it was very hard having to deliver news to people and not being able to comfort them, having to keep a distance. And so I talked to you about a little over two weeks ago. And I'm wondering, has that gotten easier for you? Have you readjusted?

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: No, it's not easier. And to be honest with you, I don't want it to be easy. If it gets easy to me, that means maybe I'm suffering from a little emotional fatigue, I'm burning out.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: If I still feel sadness, that's a good thing. I mean, it sucks, but it's a good thing. It means I'm still feeling. In my head, I try to remember that the sun does come out the next day. And I know that sounds corny, but it's awfully cloudy at the moment.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Yeah.

speaker: anthony almojera
utterance: But the thing that's hard about this is, as a medic, you are eternally hopeful in the face of fighting death every day. Because even if you didn't get them this time, you know that the next time you will. But this virus out here, this pandemic, we're not getting them next time.

speaker: miki meek
utterance: Right now about 15% of the emergency medical service workers for the New York Fire Department are out on sick leave. At least three are in the ICU on ventilators. And one longtime worker, a watch commander in downtown Brooklyn named Greg Hodge, died earlier this week from COVID. Anthony took this news hard. He says Greg is the one who trained him when he first came on the job.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Miki Meek is one of the producers of our show. Just a program note after that story-- if you or somebody you know might need help, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is available 24/7 at 1-800-273-TALK. That's 1-800-273-8255.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: By the way, the EMS unions in New York City have been in a dispute with city government. Starting pay for an EMT in New York is roughly $35,000. Paramedics start at $48,000. And when the pandemic started, they asked for hazard pay since they were putting their lives on the line in a way that was more than usual and also for better benefits for their families if they should die on the job. They have gotten nowhere with this. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has said he will look into it, but not until the crisis is over.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Our program was produced today by Robyn Semien. People who put our show together today includes Bim Adewunmi, Emanuele Berry, Zoe Chace, Dana Chivvis, Sean Cole, Aviva DeKornfeld, Nora Gill, Damian Grave, Miki Meek, Stowe Nelson, Katherine Rae Mondo, Ben Phelan, Nadia Reiman, Christopher Swetala, and Matt Tierney, the managing editors Diane Wu and Sara Abdurrahman, our executive editor, David Kestenbaum. Interpreters who helped us with our story in Act One, Samar Jan and Nasir Siddique.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Esther Perel's podcast, Where Shall We Begin? that we talked about at the top of the show is now available on Spotify and any other platform where you get your podcasts. Special thanks today to Darren Viler, Max Baucus, David Brophy, Sue Benet Romere, Usan Uyghur, and Kayla Gabler. Our website, thisamericanlife.org. This American Life is delivered to public radio stations by PRX, the Public Radio Exchange.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Thanks, as always, to our program's co-founder, Mr. Torey Malatia. While on lockdown these last few weeks, he's been working on his relationship. His wife has an old Al Green record that they like to snuggle to.

speaker: esther perel
utterance: It's an accelerator. It's a relationship accelerator.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: I'm Ira Glass, back next week with more stories of This American Life.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: There's the part of you that's healthy, and there's the part of you that's sick. And sometimes the healthy part doesn't want to admit there's a sick part. Well, back in 1945, Walt Strommer was wounded in the Battle of the Bulge. He was permanently blinded, sent home.

ep-71.speaker: walt strommer
ep-71.utterance: For the next year or so, when I was back home going to college, I would dream that I was driving a car. And then in the dream I would think, "You shouldn't be doing this. You're blind."

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: In fact, he realized, in his dream, he was always able to see. And even to this day, over 50 years later, he still has these dreams from time to time.

ep-71.speaker: walt strommer
ep-71.utterance: Sometimes I will dream of myself as I was as a teenager. And those dreams are almost completely as I would have been then, seeing. Or occasionally, I will still, in dreams, see a page of a book and read it, and absolutely clearly, and I may even remember a sentence or two when I wake up.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: Mr. Strommer says it took 10 or 15 years of blindness before he showed up in his own dreams as a blind person. And at some point, he started to wonder, "Why the delay?" He wrote a letter to a publication called Paraplegia  News asking if anybody else had the same experience. He got a handful of letters from people who had.

ep-71.speaker: walt strommer
ep-71.utterance: Some of them started seeing themselves as in wheelchairs or paralyzed-- whatever-- within a few months. Others it was years before it was incorporated. And I think almost all of them say it's inconsistent. Sometimes they will see themselves as in a wheelchair, the next time not. I think one of the more amusing ones was the man who said he would go along in his wheelchair and he gets to a curb that the chair won't get up on. So he gets out of the chair, lifts it up on the curb, and then he gets back in and goes on his way. Or one woman wrote about she will dream that she's walking with her husband, and he's pushing her wheelchair. And then he sees somebody coming. He says, "Quick, get back in your wheelchair. People are coming."

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: Here's a letter that you were sent. An older man writes, "I've been in a wheelchair since October 6, 1966. And during the dream state, I've never visualized myself in a wheelchair. I've been impotent since 1962, but in dreams, I see myself as a stud that can go out with any of the cute, young things."

ep-71.speaker: walt strommer
ep-71.utterance: Yes. That comes through in a couple of the letters. And as I recall, one of the people wrote-- I guess I had raised the question, why doesn't the dreaming brain catch up and show you the reality? And she said, "Why should it? Why should it be in a hurry to show us the unpleasant side of life? Maybe part of the function of dreams is to give us a few minutes of respite and happiness so we can come out of it and say, 'Hey, that felt pretty good.'"

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: One man, a wheelchair user, wrote, "This is better than just a harmless fantasy. It means I can re-experience walking and running temporarily. I wake up mentally refreshed, at ease." Mr. Strommer was a college professor, and he spent some time researching why our subconscious minds would take so long to absorb the new facts about our lives, why his brain took a decade to admit to itself in dreams that he was blind. He says nobody really knows why. It might be chemical, or it might simply be that it's common for us all to see ourselves one way when in reality we're not that way at all.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: Well, from WBEZ Chicago and Public Radio International, it is This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. Today on our program, Defying Sickness. Act One, Road Trip. A father and a son go on a long car ride to figure out what parts of the father's brain have not been lost yet to Alzheimer's disease and to try to jump-start his memories. Act Two, My World Record, a hemophiliac's adventures at motocross racing and at setting another world's record. Act Three-- well, just stay tuned for Act Three. We'll launch Act One after some music.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: Act One, Road Trip. Joel Meyerowitz is a photographer, grew up in New York City. But for the last two decades, his parents have lived in Florida. Joel would see them, visit for a few days at a time. But over the past 10 years, Joel's father, Hy, developed Alzheimer's. Before he retired, Hy was a salesman for 40 years and did a few years as a comic in a vaudeville act before that. He was a boxer, won his weight class in the very first Golden Gloves competition. But now that he had Alzheimer's, the doctor said that he should stay inside, avoid a lot of stimulation. His son Joel thought, "What if we try, just for a brief time, something different?"

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I was visiting my father. We were driving someplace and he was babbling on, as he does. His great skill is that he can talk. And in the middle of one of these riffs, he turned to me with a look of panic, really, and he said, "The trouble with me is I never get to the point where I get to the point." And that was so pungent an observation about his predicament that it entered my consciousness in a way that made me say, now. That's it. I'm going to make a film about him. He's at a place in this disease where, before he's completely gone and while he has some consciousness about his situation, I'm going to take him out into the world again and see what happens to him and how he handles himself.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: They got a camera and went on a three-week trip, driving from Ft. Lauderdale back to New York City. Joel Meyerowitz's son Sasha did most of the filming. You hear his voice only a few times in the footage I'm about to play you. When they set out on the trip, Sasha was 27, Joel was 57, Hy was 87.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Do you know what ocean this is?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Well, I'll be honest with you, Joel. I don't remember. Not the Catskills Ocean--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: The Catskills are mountains. This is an ocean. Which one?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Well, I don't know.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Is it the Pacific or the Atlantic?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I will take that as Pacific.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Really?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Wrong.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Wrong?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah, wrong.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: So which one is it then?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: It's the permiss- permission of--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: The Permishic. Right.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: The Permishic!

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: The Farshimmelt. The Farshimmelt Ocean.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I am a bissel farshimmelt! What are you asking me so early in the morning a question like that?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Where were you born?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Well, it was East 100th Street, right?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah. Yeah.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: He taught me all the street-smart things. He set up a punching bag for me. And he taught me how to fight, how to take my stance, how to throw a punch, how to put your body behind it. He had me work out on a light bag too, like this. He always felt that if you got into a scrape in the neighborhood that you shouldn't run away. His motto was, "Step in and deliver the first blow." And he said, "Take the biggest guy down."

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: And that was his attitude. He wouldn't stop and run away from anything. On Morrison Avenue, the block we lived on, he was considered the mayor of the block. Anytime there was a dispute that had to be settled, they would actually come and ask him, "What do you think, Hy?" Or if there were strangers coming through the neighborhood and they needed to be told to get out of there, they'd get him. And the scenes I remember of it, people would gather in front of our window, and they'd yell, "Hymie? Hey, Hymie?" And he'd come to the window and he would adjudicate from the window. He would say, "No, no. You shouldn't do that. And he should do this. And you get that. Let him alone." And it was like The Judge.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Here we come, baby. And I want you to know-- hey you!

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Hello! Hello! Hello! Hello!

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Hey, Pop?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: You know what this reminds me of?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: No.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Does that remind you of Melvin?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Oh, yeah.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: That's what I was thinking.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I didn't think of the name at that time.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Do you remember Melvin?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah. Sure I remember him.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What was Melvin?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: He was a little Chinese little bird.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: A parakeet.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: A parakeet. Right. I didn't think--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Do you remember the things that Melvin said?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: He called us, he spoke to us, and he also called his name out a lot.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah, but how did he say it? Do you remember?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: "I'm Mel-- I'm Melvin!" Isn't it, isn't it, "Hi, Belvin?"

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: No, he said, "I'm Melvin--" what?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Melvin Belvin?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: "I'm Melvin Meyerowitz."

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Oh, yeah.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Can you tell me the story of the time he got lost--

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I can't tell you about-- look at this. I can't tell you about any-- look at this. Another one comes. Hiya, boys! Hello! Hello! We know you! We know your grandfather!

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Pop, remember how he used to say "My name is Melvin Meyerowitz. I'm a Jewish bird."

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah. Yes.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: That comes back to you?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I know it. It didn't but that--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: "Good morning, Dr. Goldberg."

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Oh, yeah.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Whenever Dr. Goldberg came to visit Mom when she was sick?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: And do you remember the time the bird flew away across the Bronx? He went out the door on Mom's shoulder and he flew away. And we were all so heartbroken that the bird was gone. And then some woman called up. Do you remember? She called mom, and she said, "Do you have a bird named Melvin?" My mother said, "Yeah, we have a bird. It was a green and yellow parakeet." And the woman said, "Well, the bird landed on my window and said, 'My name is Melvin Meyerowitz. I'm a Jewish bird.' And I looked you up in the phone book, and I called the Meyerowitz's, and they said, 'No, no. That's my brother Hy's bird.'" We went and we got the bird back. Do you remember that?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: No.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I'm surprised.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Come on! You don't want to go? Don't fall! Take it easy, take it easy. Do you want to go?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: With the onset of memory loss, it's not only his memories that are fading away, but it's the memories that I shared with him that are fading away. So I could no longer say to him, "Hey Pop, remember we did this?" And have him say, "Yes, that was fantastic. Remember it?" So I found myself progressively left alone with my memories. And then you look at your own memories and you realize, I got this handful of really insignificant things, and I've made them my world, my world of memory.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: And it's astonishing how the few things that I recall to share with him are minor notes. The bird or the handful of things that I ask him. So that was really-- that was a lesson for me about what it is that rises up out of our experience that we hold onto.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Pop.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yes?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I want to ask you a few questions about the family.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: About our family?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: About our family.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yes.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: You've got three sons.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yes.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What are their names?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Joel, Ricky--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: And who's your youngest son?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: The youngest one is-- I think it was David. I don't remember the name anymore.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Joel, Rick, and--?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Joel, Ricky, and-- yeah.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Stevie.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Stevie. Oh, yeah.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: OK. Do you know what Rick does to make a living? what his career is?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Well, he tries to do a lot of stuff for you. If he were following me, he would be doing it on the crook. But--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What's he famous for?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Ricky? Well, in the first place, he's my kid. You are also. And because that alone gives you enough fame.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: So you don't remember what Rick does?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Ricky? Rick is a half-time, or part-time book-- I don't know the trade names.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: You're getting closer, Pop. Just try. Try to think about what Rick does.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Rick? Rick is an artist.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Right! You got it.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Not what?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: You got it right. And I'm Joel. What do I do?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: You're a doll. You're my best number one!

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I know. Come on. Get serious, Pop. Do you remember what it is I do? What do I do?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: You make money. I'll tell you what, I'll give it to you straight off the street.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What's my profession?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What's what?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What's my profession?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What's your most attachment?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What's my profession?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Your profession. Now I've got to figure out-- I don't know. Crook or thief or whatever. You're known as an artist. Serious artist in the art field.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: OK, what about Stevie? What's Stevie's business?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Judy?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Stevie.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Stevie? I don't know.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Does it bother you that you can't remember your kids' names sometimes and you can't remember what they do?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Well, I'll tell you, yeah. I see them-- "Hello, goodbye." And that's it. I'm not complaining.

ep-71.speaker: sasha meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Is it hard to see him like this? Does it feel painful?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Honestly, it's sad. I have a feeling of sadness, but I also have a feeling of acceptance. We've been apart for 20 years in the mutual prime of our lives when I was raising my children and he was a grandparent. We weren't together.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: And so I guess I'm just accepting of where he is. If we had been together for 20 years and I had seen the decline and I had been relating to him emotionally and lovingly all that time, I might feel a deeper sadness. But even though he's my father, the distance that we've been apart all these years has put some kind of a buffer in there. So this is the guy that I know now.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: We have a much closer relationship, the way we see each other and talk to each other and have continuity.

ep-71.speaker: sasha meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I just know at one point, you said to him he was your hero, which I thought was so sweet and I thought it must be hard to see--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: A hero fall.

ep-71.speaker: sasha meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Right.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Well, he was my hero. My childhood hero. But that's so far away, I can't relate to the sadness of that. I love him in that unequivocal way that a child loves a parent. And I feel when I care for him a kind of renewal or a rebirth of feeling in this period.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I know when I take him after a shower and I rub him down, I actually feel his head in my hands and I feel his flesh in my hands. It's been many years since I had that kind of contact with my father. And it was a little strange at first. I thought, "What's it like to rub this other person's body? Touch this other person's body?" It's like deference. And then I realize it's my Pop. And he's in need. He can't take care of himself this way.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Mom? OK, here's Papa, Mom. Hold on. OK, here comes Dad.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Joel? Is it my Joel? Don't you know who I am? Who? What do you mean, "How come I'm on the phone?" Don't get mad at me. Don't get mad at me. It's very important because I've been traveling. I didn't--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I think my father had a classic marriage of his generation. He loved my mother. She was beautiful and hot tempered, an exciting person to be with. But he wanted something from her that either he didn't know how to get or she couldn't give. And that was a kind of mother-love that he himself hadn't experienced.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yes, I'm OK. No, I'm not having a good time. Are you having a good time? You are, really? OK. I want you to be healthy and strong and smile, Sally.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: His mother had been bed-ridden after his birth. And then she died soon after. So he never really knew her. That's the deepest groove in his memory, which is, I think, unrequited love.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Don't go down the judge's because right now I'm beginning the first one of Joel's tests. And I will be back at home maybe-- who knows? A couple of months from now. I don't know, Sally. Would you go with me the next trip? Would you go with me the next trip? OK. All right, May. Take care, sweetheart. Be careful, will you? Be careful. Bye bye.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: And I think from my point of view now that if he had really just loved my mother without demanding something from her, or needing something from her, which was that childhood need, that she probably would have just loved him back for the kind, warm, funny man that he was. But because there was something that he was demanding, she couldn't give it to him. A kind of perverse logic of relationship occurred.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: She's mad. She's mad about something. Mad about me. I didn't do nothing.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Why is she mad?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: She's mad, that's all. She sounded very, very mad. She sounded like she didn't care.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Well, she probably was caring a lot--

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Oh, sure.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: --which is why she was mad. That we didn't call.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I waver also when I think of her being by herself. And I would rather be there than be here.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: But you're having such a good time here.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah, to my limit, I'm having what I like and I would love to do, love to be involved with. But the idea is that I always have to include Mama.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Throughout the trip, he asked for Sally every single day-- "Where's Sally? Where's Mom?"-- thinking that she should have been in the car next to him.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Sally? Did you leave Sally upstairs there?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah, Pop. We said goodbye to Mom.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: No kidding. Right. Because I noticed right here that this is no Sally. I thought this was Sally all bundled up and I see it's that bundled up.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: It's your pillow. That pillow's going to have to be your Sally--

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Yeah, yeah. The pillow.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: --for at least two weeks now.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Oh, you guys are starting to pull tricks on me now. I know, I know, I know. Well, is she here?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Nope. That's your pillow, Pop.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Jesus Christ almighty. I know she's not in the trunk. You wouldn't do that to her. I'm not able to come to this, Joel. I'm not the smartest and the cutest and the swiftest. I--

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: If my Mommy--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: The swiftest!

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: If my Mommy don't come up and then don't come down in five minutes, I want to know where she is. This is my wife.

ep-71.speaker: sasha meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: So we better check the trunk.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Oh, the bed is in the trunk?

ep-71.speaker: sasha meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: No.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I wouldn't be surprised.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: There was a time when we were driving with her in Florida, before we made the film. And she was sitting right next to him. And he leaned over to me and he said, "Where's Mom?" ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: You can see better with this.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Good morning.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Good morning to you!

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Good morning, Pop.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Hiya, Sonny.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: How are you doing?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I don't really know.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: His real intelligence is to live in the moment. He knew where he was and he was just enjoying the experience. But he couldn't really look back at what he had done even an hour before and remember it. And I tested him all the time, because I wanted to see if stimulation could actually enliven his mentality and bring him back at all. But that was sort of a hopeless hope. But it didn't stop me from having it anyway.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I just want to review a few things with you. I have a few questions for you.

ep-71.utterance: Uh, I'm not-- I don't have to call my attorney?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: No.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: No. OK.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Do you remember any of the things on the trip so far?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: But will you-- I'm just going to say. Don't ask me about anything I did.

ep-71.utterance: Why?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Why? Because that's gone, man.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: It's gone.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Not that-- it wasn't so many things going on. But I just don't remember. It's jumbled. I've been to a car. I went to the automobile. I've been to the train. I was going in every direction. And I was losing sight. I was losing sight for no reason whatsoever. Everybody was going around us. Turmoil. Turmoiled.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: To moil?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: To moil?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: To moil?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: To moil is not to moil, but to moil is to have and to kiss and to love, to moil!

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: "Respect the old man who--" wait, wait. I can wear glasses.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: "Ark."

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: "Repsect the old man who has forgotten what he has learned. For broken tablets have a place in the mind-- in the ark, excuse me-- the ark besides the tablets of the law." Didn't I have my glasses here?

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: OK, now read it-- do you want my glasses?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: When my father was young, he was a wonderful dancer and athlete and a natural comic. And I guess Charlie Chaplin was the rage, and just as there were Elvis imitators, there were Chaplin imitators. And my father, he became a Chaplin imitator. And he had that act that I guess he took on the road, or around the vaudeville circuit in New York.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I was trying to fit in myself, through all the years with the joking. I was trying to be a Chaplin. I didn't know if I was doing that right or wrong, but I saw that poor little guy, that he bent down, picked something up, everybody'd give him a kick in the ass. That was what I used to see. That is what I didn't want to happen to me.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: What was it that you liked about Charlie Chaplin that made you want to do the Charlie Chaplin act?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: He was a giant in the height of a little midget. He was a little guy, went righting all the wrongs, helping others as he passed by. We'd pat him on the top of the head. He was remembered out there, just for a minute. He'd have a little [UNINTELLIGIBLE] with a little person hat and no money or no nothing. And he would go inside and he'd come out here like this. Like, shake his shoulders, and then travel around.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: And that was what I loved, the goodness, the goodness. And not everybody understood him. But those that understood him, they would put their arm around him and he would do the same with them. It was a beautiful deed for the day.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Did you feel connected to him in that way?

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Always. [CHOKING UP] Always. Always.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Aw--

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: With Alzheimer's disease, most memory finally dissolves. And even though he was a man who was easily lovable, I think he forgot that these were his qualities. And that he was, in fact, loved by people faded from his memory. And at the end of his life, he remembers a few of the more painful things-- that he's a motherless child, that he was not loved the way he wanted to be loved. And it's amazing that with the murkiness of Alzheimer's clouding everything, that something as primal as being an unloved child stayed with him.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: When anybody would show a little bit of something to me that I was accepted, and they would talk to me, and they'd pat me on the top of the head of put their hands around me, I'm home. I loved everybody. I loved everybody. But nobody saw me. Nobody remembered me. Nobody knew me. Nobody saw me. But I was there. To this very day, I have the same fear. I have poor Mommy, I have. And she doesn't see me. She doesn't see me.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: Oh, Papa. Well, your boys saw you. We all saw you. I loved when you were the strong man in the neighborhood. I loved when you were the Chaplin figure and the comic. I loved the way you drove the car. You were such a great driver.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: I love the way you talk to people. You could talk to the big guys or the little guys, and you made them all the same, Pop. I used to think of you as the great equalizer. You could take a guy who was a doctor or a principal of the school or a business man, and you can take another guy who was just an ordinary worker, and you would treat them the same. And you would bring them all to the same level, and that would be the level of laughter.

ep-71.speaker: hy meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: You saw me. You saw Papa.

ep-71.speaker: joel meyerowitz
ep-71.utterance: That's right.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: Joel Meyerowitz. His father Hy, his son Sasha. Their film has the working title The Mayor of the Block and is looking for a distributor. Coming up, people do what they shouldn't. In a minute from Public Radio International when our program continues.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: We have arrived at Act Two of our show, My World Record. This is from a book by Tom Andrews called The Hemophiliac's  Motorcycle.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: On November 15, 1972, one week after Nixon was reelected, I clapped my hands for 14 hours and 31 minutes.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: I was listed in The Guinness Book of World Records. I was 11 years old.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: My record was published on page 449 of the 1974 edition of The Guinness Book, landlocked between the listings for largest circus and club swinging in the chapter entitled "Human Achievements." The listing read, "Clapping. The duration record for continuous clapping is 14 hours, 31 minutes by Thomas C. Andrews at Charleston, West Virginia on November 15, 1972. He sustained an average of 120 claps per minute at an audibility range of at least 100 yards."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: I'm writing this from my bed at the University of Michigan hospital. It is 3:00 AM. It is the half-dark of hospitals at night. I've had an accident. I have been in an accident.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "That your scrapbook?" Ellen, the night nurse, asked. When I mutter that technically it's my mother's who brought it to the hospital to cheer me up, Ellen glances at the Inquirer headline and says, "You did that, clap your hands?" I nod. "Lord! Did you have a major bleed, or what?"

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Dear Tom, it was certainly nice to read that you had broken the world record in clapping. We used to enjoy seeing how your dad recorded you and John in your annual picture for Christmas. The last few years, we had lost contact. Congratulations again. Everyone is very proud of you. Sincerely, the Ripley-Fishers."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Dear Tom, try to come out if you can. But if you can't, that's OK. I can play until about 4:00 or 5:00. I hope you come out. Will you walk with me today? Circle yes or no. I think you are the nicest boy over in Rolling Hills. I'm going to try to get you something. Love, Diane. PS-- write back if you want to. Don't let anybody else see this except Nan. If you want to. Or Laura. I just showed Nan and Laura. Do you mind? Circle yes or no. Answer questions and give back please."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: I have had an accident on the sidewalk. I watched my feet come out from under me on the iced concrete with a kind of anecdotal perspective. The bleeding inside the joints, the infusions of factor VIII, the weeks of immobility, the waiting for codeine, the inventions with which my mind would veer in the direction of solid ground. As my weight drilled into the twisting leg, I saw the whole pantomime emerge with the clarity of blown glass.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: When I told my hematologist that as a teenager I had raced motocross, that in fact in one race in Gallipolis, Ohio, I had gotten the holeshot and was bumped in the first turn and run over by 20-some motorcycles, she said, "No. Not with your factor level. I'm sorry but you wouldn't withstand the head injuries. You just like the sound of yourself being dramatic."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Does he have to do that?" the waitress at the Pizza Hut asked. She passed out glasses of ice water from a tray, then set the tray down on the table.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "He's breaking a world record," John said flatly.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Does it bother you?" my mother said. "I can't make him stop, but we can leave."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: The waitress looked up. "You're joking, right? Let me see." She gestured for me to pull up my hands out from under the table. I showed my hands.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "He has to sustain an audibility range of at least 100 yards," John said.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "I'm getting the cook," she said. "He's got to see this."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: A minute later, a man with botched teeth wearing a blue, dough-smeared apron was glaring at me. "Well?" he said, impatiently. Again I showed my hands. I speeded up just a little the rate of clapping. "Right. Unbelievable," the cook said, shaking his head and disappearing.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: I said, "Can we order?"

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "What do you do if you have to go to the bathroom?" the waitress asked.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "I'd like a root beer," I said. "Do you have root beer?"

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "He's trying to go the whole day without going," my mother said.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Good luck," the waitress said.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: I said, "Do you have root beer?"

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Yeah, they have root beer," John said.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: I said, "I was asking her, thank you very much."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "I don't think I could go the whole day," the waitress said. "I think I have a weak bladder." I leaned over to John and whispered, "Help."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Hey," said the waitress, "how are you going to eat pizza?"

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "I'm not," I said. "I'm just sipping some root beer. If you have it."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "They have it. They have it," John said. John buried his head in his hands.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "I'm going to feed him," my mother said.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "No way," I said. For a second I forgot to clap, then caught myself and reestablished my rhythm.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "We'll have a large mushroom and pepperoni," my mother said, "and I'd like a glass of iced tea. What do you want to drink?"

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "I want a Coke," John said.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Root beer," I said.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: There are times in the last minutes before I am allowed-- or allow myself-- more codeine when the pain inside the joint simplifies me utterly. I feel myself descending some kind of evolutionary ladder until I become as crude and guileless as an amoeba. The pain is not personal. I am incidental to it. It is like faith, the believer eclipsed by something immense.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: After the waitress left, my mother lectured me about not participating in events we scheduled on John's off days, days when he wasn't on the dialysis machine. "You've known for a week that we were coming here. You could have picked another day for this clapping business." She said this in front of John, who grimaced and began looking around the room.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: My argument was that just being there at Pizza Hut while I was in the crucial early hours of breaking a world record was sufficient participation, and that sipping a little root beer under the circumstances put me solidly in the off-day spirit of things. She didn't see it that way.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: What surprised me was how easy it was to keep a precise and consistent rhythm. Two hours into the record, I felt as if my hands, like the legs of runners who have broken through the wall, could hammer away at themselves effortlessly and indefinitely. At that point, I knew I would not start a bleed. I had no doubt. And yet my hands kept hammering at themselves, hammering.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Nixon's problem is he's not eating right," my mother said. "It's as plain as day. Anyone can see it. Just look at the man." It was 5:30 PM and I was still at it, 120 claps per minute.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: "Care for a drink?" my father said to himself. "Don't mind if I do. Thank you for asking."

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: For a long time, I asked John to come and watch me race. Again and again, he refused. Finally, he agreed to come to a race at Hidden Hills Raceway in Gallipolis, Ohio-- to shut me up, I think, as much as to satisfy his curiosity about his hemophiliac brother racing a motorcycle across the gouged wilderness. I knew John would have to wear a plastic bag over his shunt arm to keep the dust out. We were lucky it rained. Dust usually billowed wildly after the start of a race, a huge rolling wave breaking over the hills and shrouding the spectators. Rain would keep the dirt moist and on the track.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: Midway through the practice sessions, however, the rain stopped. By the time of the first 125 moto, dust forced John into the cab of the pickup. That is the image that attacks me now-- John in the truck, windows rolled up, reading a book to pass the time while I kicked up the dust all around him.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: Random symmetries. Days when John's shunt clotted and he required I forget how many cc's of heparin to get his blood to stop coagulating. Meanwhile, I'd start a bleed and would need cryoprecipitate or factor VIII to get my blood to clot.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: More x-rays. I've stopped bleeding into the spinal muscles. Soon enough, my hematologist says my body will loosen and break down and absorb the hardened blood surrounding the spine, as it had been doing in my leg. There has been no intraspinal bleeding, no bleeding into the kidney or liver. I look at Carrie. I look at my mother and father. We are inside a sudden, astonishing calm. I seem to levitate and hover over the white sheets.

ep-71.speaker: frank melcori
ep-71.utterance: Once when John was dialyzing, I tripped into the machine and jerked a tube clean out of its socket. John's blood pumped and sprayed into the air, splattering across the carpet and splotching our skin and clothes. My mother worked frantically to reconnect the tube and to stabilize John's blood pressure. Later, I noticed that some of the blood had seeped inside a picture frame in the wall besides the dialysis chair. The frame held a photograph of John and me. We were wading in the Kanawha River, staring hard at the gray water.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: Excerpts from Tom Andrews' prose poem "Codeine Diary." It's in his book The Hemophiliac's  Motorcycle and was read by Frank Melcori.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: Act Three, Iron Man. All of our stories today have been at one level about yearning briefly fulfilled. And we thought this last story would be a perfect way to end this show. Mark O'Brien is a writer living in California, but because of a childhood case of polio, he lives most of each day in an iron lung, on his back. He's the subject of the documentary film Breathing Lessons by Jessica Yu. The film is remarkable because it's about a guy in an iron long, but it is completely unsentimental. There are even parts where it's funny.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: This is a brief scene from the film. Because he's in the iron lung, Mark O'Brien has attendants. They cook and they help him out during the day. And during the film, he explains that nowadays he always has men do this job. Because back when he had women do the job, he kept falling in love with these women, and the love was never reciprocated. He wrote about one of these women, "Her pale, perfect skin, her strong, fleshy legs drove me to ecstasies of despair. See, she talked to me as a human instead of her savagely crippled employer."

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: A quick warning before I play this very brief scene. It contains mild sexual content that may not be suitable for every listener.

ep-71.speaker: mark o'brien
ep-71.utterance: I hired a sex-surrogate in-- '87 or '86. I forget when. I just-- felt very crazy. I was-- angry at all women for not falling in love-- with me, because I had fallen in love with several-- attendants. And they-- all said it was a business rela-- tionship.

ep-71.speaker: mark o'brien
ep-71.utterance: A sex surrogate's a person who has some of psychological training that-- works with their body, having sex with a client who's recruited by a therapist. The surrogate had this big mirror and she-- saw me naked and aroused. And-- at the time, I thought I was the ugliest man in the world. I looked just like something someone-- wouldn't want to have sex with.

ep-71.speaker: mark o'brien
ep-71.utterance: And Cheryl was very kind to me. She kissed me on the chest after-- we had intercourse. I felt my-- chest was very unattractive, but-- she kissed me right there. And-- the intercourse was so quick, it just-- I hate to say it, but it was wham, bam, thank you ma'am. And it-- wasn't as great as I thought it would be, but-- being naked in a bed with a woman who's being extremely friendly was the-- most fun I've ever had. I think I'd like to do it again.

ep-71.speaker: ira glass
ep-71.utterance: Usually Mark O'Brien can't be outside of his iron lung for more than 45 minutes. But when the sex surrogate was with him, he was outside his tube for longer than that, longer than he almost every goes out. And he didn't even use his portable respirator.

ep-71.speaker: mark o'brien
ep-71.utterance: I didn't need it for an hour. I went for-- an hour without it. It makes you think of sex as respiratory-- therapy. Maybe Medi-Cal would pay for it. About a year after I last saw her, I just felt terribly depressed. I expected somehow that seeing the surrogate would change my life. I had started wearing cologne. And I thought everyone would be able to tell if I was sexy and handsome.
